q: What are the symptoms of tailbone (coccyx) pain?
a: The main symptom of tailbone (coccyx) pain is pain and tenderness at the base of your spine, near the top of your bottom. It may feel dull and achy most of the time, with occasional sharp pains. The pain may worsen while sitting, bending forward, or during activities like having a bowel movement, sex, or during your period. You may also have difficulty sleeping and carrying out daily activities.

q: How can I ease tailbone (coccyx) pain myself?
a: To ease tailbone (coccyx) pain yourself, you can try maintaining good posture with lower back support, using a specially designed coccyx cushion or exercise ball when sitting, lying on your side to reduce coccyx pressure, doing pelvic floor exercises, using ice or heat packs on the affected area, taking non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) like ibuprofen, and using a laxative to soften stool if pain worsens during bowel movements. It's important to avoid sitting for prolonged periods and wearing tight clothes around your bottom and lower back.

q: When should I see a GP for tailbone (coccyx) pain?
a: You should see a GP for tailbone (coccyx) pain if it hasn't improved after a few weeks of home treatments, if it's affecting your daily activities, or if you have a high temperature along with tailbone pain and pain in other areas such as your tummy or lower back.

q: What are the treatments for tailbone (coccyx) pain?
a: If simple treatments like pelvic floor exercises and ibuprofen haven't helped, further treatments may be recommended. These include physiotherapy to manipulate the muscles around the coccyx and corticosteroid and local anaesthetic injections into the joint that attaches the coccyx to the bottom of the spine. Surgery to remove part or all of the coccyx may be recommended if other treatments don't reduce the pain.

q: What are some common causes of tailbone (coccyx) pain?
a: Common causes of tailbone (coccyx) pain include pregnancy and childbirth, injuries or accidents like falling onto the coccyx, repeated or prolonged strain on the coccyx (e.g., sitting for a long time while driving or cycling), poor posture, being overweight or underweight, and joint hypermobility of the joint that attaches the coccyx to the bottom of the spine. Sometimes the cause of tailbone pain is unknown.

q: Can physiotherapy help with tailbone (coccyx) pain?
a: Yes, physiotherapy can be recommended to help ease tailbone (coccyx) pain. The muscles around the coccyx can be manipulated through physiotherapy to aid in pain relief.

q: What injections can be given for tailbone (coccyx) pain?
a: Corticosteroid and local anaesthetic injections can be given into the joint that attaches the coccyx to the bottom of the spine to help reduce tailbone (coccyx) pain. Usually, a maximum of 2 injections is given over consecutive months.

q: Is surgery an option for tailbone (coccyx) pain?
a: Yes, if other treatments haven't helped in reducing tailbone (coccyx) pain, surgery to remove part or all of the coccyx may be recommended.

q: What can I do to sit correctly and maintain good posture?
a: To sit correctly and maintain good posture, make sure your lower back is supported, and avoid slouching. You can also use a specially designed coccyx cushion or an exercise ball to help maintain proper posture while sitting.

q: How long does tailbone (coccyx) pain usually last?
a: Tailbone (coccyx) pain may improve after a few weeks, but it can sometimes last longer. If the pain persists, it's recommended to seek medical advice.

q: What are the main symptoms of tailbone (coccyx) pain?
a: The main symptoms of tailbone (coccyx) pain include pain and tenderness at the base of the spine, dull and achy pain with occasional sharp pains, difficulty sleeping and carrying out daily activities.

q: How can I ease tailbone (coccyx) pain myself?
a: You can ease tailbone (coccyx) pain yourself by maintaining good posture, using a specially designed coccyx cushion when sitting, lying on your side to reduce pressure, doing pelvic floor exercises, using ice or heat packs, using non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), and using a laxative to soften your stool if needed.

q: When should I see a GP for tailbone (coccyx) pain?
a: You should see a GP if your tailbone (coccyx) pain does not improve after a few weeks of trying home treatments, if the pain is affecting your daily activities, or if you have a high temperature and pain in another area such as your tummy or lower back.

q: What treatments are available for tailbone (coccyx) pain?
a: Further treatments for tailbone (coccyx) pain include physiotherapy to manipulate the muscles around the coccyx, corticosteroid and local anaesthetic injections into the joint that attaches the coccyx to the spine, and in some cases, surgery to remove part or all of the coccyx.

q: What are the common causes of tailbone (coccyx) pain?
a: Common causes of tailbone (coccyx) pain include pregnancy and childbirth, injuries or accidents, repeated or prolonged strain on the coccyx, poor posture, being overweight or underweight, and joint hypermobility. Sometimes the cause is unknown.

q: Is tailbone (coccyx) pain more common in pregnant women?
a: Yes, tailbone (coccyx) pain is more common in pregnant women due to the increased strain on the coccyx during pregnancy.

q: Can sitting for a long time worsen tailbone (coccyx) pain?
a: Yes, sitting for a long time can worsen tailbone (coccyx) pain, especially if you have poor posture or if you already have strain on the coccyx.

q: Are there any medications that can help with tailbone (coccyx) pain?
a: Yes, non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) like ibuprofen can help reduce the pain associated with tailbone (coccyx) pain.

q: Can I use heat or ice packs to alleviate tailbone (coccyx) pain?
a: Yes, you can use an ice pack or a heat pack wrapped in a towel on the affected area for 20 to 30 minutes to help alleviate tailbone (coccyx) pain.

q: Is surgery always necessary for tailbone (coccyx) pain?
a: No, surgery is not always necessary for tailbone (coccyx) pain. It is usually considered as a treatment option if other treatments like physiotherapy and injections have not helped in reducing the pain.
